urn:contentItem:5R7N-DJP1-F00X-J06M-00000-00Apple to $1 Trillion, Big FANG Gains, Disney vs. Hulu: Top Tech Trends in 20182017-12-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:55ZLexisNexisApple to $1 Trillion, Big FANG Gains, Disney vs. Hulu: Top Tech Trends in 2018Annie Palmer

Silicon Valley giants will move on to bigger and better things in 2018.

No corner of the stock market has had as good of a year as the tech sector.


In particular, the 'FAANG' stocks -- Facebook Inc. , Amazon.com Inc. , Apple Inc. , Netflix Inc.and Alphabet Inc.-- have dominated the market, with many up more than 50% in 2017, which is higher than the Nasdaq's rise of 29.3% so far this year.




Some experts believe that tech's stunning run in 2018, as investors moderate their view of earnings growth over value and other macroeconomic factors take shape, including possible negative effects from the Federal Communications Commission's decision to end net neutrality.


Not everyone shares that view, however. GBH Insights analyst Daniel Ives believes that FAANG stocks, especially, are in the "pole position" in tech next year. The regulatory environment, corporate tax changes and the broader macro backdrop are likely to create challenges and opportunities for the big tech names in 2018, he said.


Still, Ives said he remains bullish on tech based on several underlying themes, including streaming/content, e-commerce growth, online ad growth and the shift to the cloud among enterprises.


Those trends should be beneficial not just for FANG names, but also for the rest of the tech sector, Ives noted. Here's his top themes for tech in 2018: Combined Disney/Fox goes head-to-head with Netflix If Walt Disney Co.is successful in completing its $52.4 billion bid for most of Twenty-First Century Fox's assets, Disney will have a strong chance of becoming the "content king," Ives said. All eyes will be focused on how Disney's direct-to-consumer platform plays out, especially once it has Fox's controlling stake of Hulu.


A marriage of these assets will allow Disney to "invade Netflix's golden streaming sandbox" as it builds a more competitive position on the content and streaming front, he added.


"We view this as a home run deal for Disney and while it's an aggressive acquisition with a high price tag, in our opinion this is the right move at the right time," Ives explained.

An iPhone X super-cycle tips Apple's market cap to $1 trillion According to Ives, all signs point to Apple enjoying an iPhone X super cycle, as existing iPhone users look to upgrade and Apple's various supply chain issues are worked out.


If an iPhone X super-cycle materializes, it could give Apple more than $12 worth of potential earnings power heading into 2019.


"With a growing services segment, a renaissance of China growth, $250+ billion of cash in the coffer (repatriation/tax code changes, buybacks, M&A could be further catalysts) and a major upgrade cycle on the horizon that Apple shares in a best case/bull case scenario could be in the $210-$230 range (17x-18x forward P/E) over the next year in our opinion and thus becoming the first member of the "trillion-dollar market cap club.," Ives said.


Apple's market cap currently hovers around $898.5 billion. The tech giant briefly flirted with a $1 trillion valuation in November when it released the 10th anniversary iPhone X. Instagram on track to hit 1 billion monthly users, which could mean big things for FacebookFacebook has been executing "extremely well" in its ad growth model and monetization, but Instagram, the company's "golden jewel," still has more room for growth, Ives said.


Instagram appears to be on track to hit 1 billion monthly active users, as its ad business continues to ramp. That could bring big gains for Facebook, as Wall Street still seems to be "underappreciating" Instagram, he added.


Monetizing Instagram to its full potential should be the "core 1-2 punch" that could help Facebook head higher in 2018, Ives said.

Amazon's Whole Foods deal starts to pay off

Amazon's significant investments around fulfillment, Prime, Echo/Alexa and Amazon Web Services could create some "near term pain for long-term gain" for investors, Ives explained.

Amazon in 2018 will be focused on further integrating its $13.7 billion acquisition of Whole Foods Market. As the internet giant optimizes its go-to-market techniques and cross-selling, that should translate to even bigger growth for Amazon's Prime subscriber network.

"With Amazon's underlying goal to increase the average customer purchase/basket size, we believe further integration between Whole Foods inventory (recent price cuts in-line with Amazon's playbook) and the Amazon e-commerce machine is a great 1-2 punch that should drive increased sales/ramp in Prime members for 2018 and is still underappreciated by the Street in our opinion," Ives said.

Amazon's ambitions in pharmacy could also become front and center in 2018. Ives believes an expansion into pharmaceuticals is a "smart strategic move" that will help it "spread its tentacles" across the consumer landscape next year.


Jim Cramer and the AAP team hold positions in Apple, Alphabet and Facebook for their Action Alerts PLUS Charitable Trust Portfolio. Want to be alerted before Cramer buys or sells AAPL, GOOGL, or FB?   Learn more now.

urn:contentItem:5WND-9T11-JBRC-V532-00000-00Apple to buy Intel modem unit2019-07-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:55ZLexisNexisBUSINESS WIRE_Pg. 1Apple to buy Intel modem unit

Apple to buy Intel modem unit Apple Inc. is buying Intel Corp.'s struggling cellular modem unit, bringing on key engineering talent and patents that will allow the technology giant to more quickly develop crucial components to connect its devices to the mobile internet. The deal is valued at $1 billion, Intel and Apple said in joint announcement.

Intel sought to shed the unit because Chief Executive Officer Bob Swan decided it was costing the chipmaker too much money to support just one customer, which is Apple. The deal will give Apple 2,200 new employees and now a total holding of 17,000 wireless patents, the companies said. Apple has been using Intel modems exclusively in iPhones since last year. Google earnings surprise SAN FRANCISCO — Google parent Alphabet beat analyst expectations for the second quarter Thursday, pleasing investors and sending its shares up sharply. The Mountain View, California-based company brought in revenue of $38.9 billion during the quarter, a 19% bump from the same period last year. The company reported profit of $14.21 per share, or $9.9 billion during the quarter, nearly triple what it made last year when it paid a $5.1 billion European Commission fine. Analysts polled by FactSet were expecting Alphabet to report earnings per share of $11.10 on revenue of $38.2 billion during the second quarter. Google is facing mounting pressure from federal elected officials and regulators over a variety of issues such as its market power, misinformation and claims — usually offered without evidence — that its popular search engine and other services are biased against conservative politicians and viewpoints. Amazon 2Q profits disappoint NEW YORK — Amazon is reporting that second quarter profits are below Wall Street estimates as increasing competition for faster delivery is putting pressure on the online leader's business. The Seattle-based company says profits for the three-month period ended June 30 was $2.62 billion, or $5.22 per share. That compares with $2.53 billion, or $5.07 per share, in the year ago quarter. Analysts had expected earnings per share of $5.56 per share, according to FactSet. The company said net sales rose 20% to $63.4 billion. That's higher than the $62.5 billion forecast by analysts. Amazon offered revenue outlook for the current quarter in line with analysts' expectations. The report comes as Amazon, along with Facebook, Google and Apple, is caught up in the swirl of investigations into Big Tech's market dominance.

urn:contentItem:5Y9N-NPX1-F12F-F4RG-00000-00Apple to open its first store in India next year2020-02-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:54ZLexisNexisApple to open its first store in India next yearBangladesh

Bangladesh, Feb. 28 -- India is finally getting its very first Apple Store, reports CNN Business.

Apple CEO Tim Cook said Wednesday that the company plans to open a brick-and-mortar store in the country in 2021. A company spokesperson confirmed the news, which was reported earlier by Reuters.

In addition to starting its own retail network, the iPhone maker will start online sales in India this year, Cook told shareholders at an annual meeting in Cupertino, California.

A big reason Apple hasn't opened a store in the country until now is that Indian regulations require foreign retailers to source at least 30 per cent of their raw materials locally - a rule that Apple has tried to seek an exemption from. The company has instead sold its devices through stores run by local partners.

Cook said Wednesday the company "needed to get approval from the government to go in there ourselves."

"I don't want somebody else to run the brand for us," he added.

A company spokesperson declined to provide further details.

With nearly 700 million internet users and almost an equal number of people yet to come online for the first time, India is too big a market to ignore.

But life is getting tougher for Big Tech in India as the government tightens restrictions on foreign companies and shows a growing tendency to shut down internet access at sensitive political moments.

urn:contentItem:5RFN-FHT1-DY0W-42K1-00000-00Apple to Repatriate Profits and Create Over 20,000 Jobs; Tax Reform Is Creating a Boom; Trump Not Backing Down on The Wall; YouTube Tries to2018-01-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:55ZLexisNexisApple to Repatriate Profits and Create Over 20,000 Jobs; Tax Reform Is Creating a Boom; Trump Not Backing Down on The Wall; YouTube Tries toLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Apple said to contribute a massive $350 billion over the next five years the technology titan will create over 20,000 jobs. Apple says it's paying it one time $38 billion tax bill to bring the cash it has previously kept overseas.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TOM COOK, CEO, APPLE: What we've been advocating for awhile is the ability to bring that back without a huge penalty. We like the repatriation agreement on the corporate tax side and we are going to bring the vast majority of it here.

BARTIROMO: The move helped drive another record close on Wall Street yesterday. Take a look at his numbers. The Dow Jones industrial average end of the session above 26,000 for the first time ever yesterday, up 322 points. Just eight trading days since it crossed the 25,000 mark, up one and a quarter percent on the Dow, better than 1 percent on the Nasdaq, up almost 1 percent on the S&P yesterday.

Let's check futures right now. We're looking at a bit of a pullback this morning. Investors waiting for key earnings in the banking sector. Morgan Stanley set to report later this morning, as soon as those numbers come in we will bring them to you. Meanwhile Morgan Stanley shares right now down two thirds of a percent ahead of its quarterly numbers.

In Europe this morning the major indices look like this, the FT 100 down 1/2 of 1 percent, the CAC Quarante in Paris and the DAX index in Germany up fractionally.

Asia overnight stocks were mostly higher. There was strong economic news out of China overnight, the economy there 6.9 percent last year, it was a bit higher than expectations, it marks the first annual acceleration of growth for China in seven years.

Plus, it is shutdown showdown. Lawmakers battling over immigration with just hours left, Republicans pushing the short-term spending bill fixes, the latest effort comes down to the wire in our nation's capital. And YouTube looking to clean things up. Holy website plastic crackdown on the dangerous Tide pod videos taking the internet by storm. All of the stories coming up.

Joining me to talk all about it CFRA investment strategist Lindsay Mills. Peebles Corporation founder chairman and CEO Don Peebles, in the "Wall Street Journal" editorial board member, Fox News contributor, Mary Kissel. Great to see you.

MARY KISSEL, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good morning everybody. What's on the agenda?

KISSEL: The budget showdown. We cannot have government shut down. It's incredible to me to see Democrats turned down a deal that would give certainty to the military, that would fund their children's healthcare program, and gives him more non-entitlement spending. So, it is giving them more money. Republicans are willing to eat that. Why won't Democrats come to the table?

BARTIROMO: All the while they said border security is important. Funding the military is important. When push comes to shove, not there.

DON PEEBLES, FOUNDER, PEEBLES CORPORATION: Typical drama on the Potomac. It always happens and sometimes they close it down but most often they work it out. It is a negotiating ploy.

BARTIROMO: When it is shut down, funding for much of the government still goes on.

PEEBLES: Absolutely, it is relatively minor.

BARTIROMO: We're talking about the implication of that. Coming up joining the conversation, White House Deputy Press Secretary Hogan Gidley is with us this morning. Texas Congressman Roger Williams is here. Former CEO of Home Depot as well as Chrysler, Bob Nardelli joins us.

Elevation Partners cofounder managing director Roger McNamee is here. And race car driver and entrepreneur, Danica Patrick joins us as well. Big three hours stay with us you don't want to miss a moment of it.

Let's take it over right here with this, jobs in America. President Trump headed to Pittsburgh to tout the booming economy following his historic tax cuts. Markets extended the gains yesterday with the Dow closing above 26,000 mark if for the first time ever. This is the eighth 1000-point milestone for the Dow since President Trump's 2016 victory.

Let's bring your global economics editor with the "Wall Street Journal," Jon Hilsenrath. Jon, good to see you thanks so much for being here, so Apple the latest company to talk about big investments in the United States. Bringing money back. Your reaction to what's happening. We are above 130 companies at this point doing something to give back to employees or constituents as a result of the tax plan.

JON HILSENRATH, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL", GLOBAL ECONOMICS EDITOR: The estimates I'm looking at how 1.5 to 2.5 trillion dollars parked by Americans overseas, with the new one time 15% tax, they have an incentive to bring money back. The important point here with respect to Apple is that a lot of those companies that park money overseas are tech companies and pharmaceutical companies. To the extent they are bringing money back to doing what Apple is doing investing in new jobs here, those tend to be pretty good jobs, tech jobs and pharmaceutical jobs. This is a shot in the arm to the United States economy. There's no way to doubt that.

BARTIROMO: Lindsay, this is a big deal, this is 20,000 new workers contributing $350 billion to the economy, and that one-time tax of 38 billion.

LINDSAY MILLS, CFRA INVESTMENT STRATEGIST: This is fantastic news. This is exactly what we want to see out of corporate America in response to the tax reform policy. The $30 billion, think about that, that is a humongous number they will spend in capital spending over the next five years.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. President Trump pushing back on Benjamin Netanyahu's comments about the U.S. embassy move in Israel. Cheryl Casone with the details there, Cheryl.

CASONE: Well, that's right, Maria. Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, said moving the U.S. embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem could be completed within a year. Well, President Trump, not on the same page. He's denying that timeline, and you may remember too that Secretary of State Tillerson said last month, the move would probably be done earlier than three years' out. That was reverse, of course, decades of the U.S. policy. President Trump, officially recognizing Jerusalem as Israel's capital last month.

Well, Amazon apparently going after budget shopping apps like Wish, for example. Amazon's now offering a new $10.00 and under the section that comes with free shipping. You don't have to belong to Amazon Prime to get this. As long as you buy something in that $10.00 under section. An interesting move. Shares of Amazon, soaring 60 percent from just a year ago.

And then there is this; just for breakfast, Krispy Kreme wants your help deciding on a new donut. They're asking all the fans to help pick one of four flavors, and they're going to add it to the menu. Here are your choices, guys: blueberry, caramel, maple, or lemon. They're all going to be glazed, by the way. So, whatever you pick, it's going to have a glaze on it. Next Wednesday, the poll is open, vote for glaze.com, and then they're going to put it in the stores, Maria, at some point in the spring, at least for a week. So, I was thinking about this really hard, I really focused, I'm going to go for blueberry, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Blueberry.

CASONE: Yes, that's where I'm at. What do you guys think?

KISSEL: Lemon.

BARTIROMO: I think I'm going to go with maple.

KISSEL: Maple?

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Glad to hear a lemon girl. Any thoughts? Are you a Dunkin Donuts guy?

PEEBLES: No, I'm not. I'm fine to stay slim as best I can, fighting the inevitable.

BARTIROMO: Dunkin Donuts or Krispy Kreme -- yes, good point, good point. Let's do that. Coming up, still bullish on Bitcoin, the largest cryptocurrency fund manager weighing in on the recent plunge, the risk and reward. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Fears of regulatory crack-down are fueling the latest Bitcoin selloff. The cryptocurrency is down nearly 50 percent since its most recent peak. My next guest one the first U.S. Bitcoin investment firm and has reported growth of over 20,000 percent since its inception in the year 2013. Joining us right now is Pantera Capital Founder and CEO, Dan Morehead. Dan, it's good to see you.

DAN MOREHEAD, FOUNDER AND CEO, PANTERA CAPITAL: Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining. So, you launched the first Bitcoin fund.

MOREHEAD: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about that. When did you do this and tell us about the growth that's been an incredible number?

MOREHEAD: Yes, in 2011, my brother told me about Bitcoin, and I realized it was this intermediate, a lot of markets, and so by 2013, we launched the first cryptocurrency fund in the U.S. And now, we've launched a handful of other funds, venture funds, and multi-currencies.

BARTIROMO: When you say -- I mean, it's a disruptor, obviously. I'm just trying to -- a long time ago Jamie Dimon said, it's a fraud, now recently I spoke with him and he said I'm sorry I said it, I wish I didn't say it. But do you think that Bitcoin is taking out the middleman -- meaning banks. Is that one reason, sort of, the big banks were skeptical?

MOREHEAD: Yes, you know, you had to pay a third party to move money around the world or to do other financial transactions. With Bitcoin, you can literally do it for free instantaneously. It's like e-mailing money.

BARTIROMO: OK.

DUFF: Well, 20,000 percent performance since 2013, why not call it quits? I mean --

MOREHEAD: You know, this is a multi-decade thing; it's like the internet. In the early '90s, you didn't know about Snapchat or, you know, all these new Uber-type applications. That's what Bitcoin is like. It's the final piece of Internet Protocol puzzle.

DUFF: Among those lines, you know, referring to by next season Maverick tickets with Bitcoins, and there are some other retailers that do accept Bitcoin, but the volatility in 2017 over five times, it's gone down 30 percent or more. You know, we saw that move in the last couple of days. That alone kind of discredits it as a currency. So, how is that going to impact its probability of, you know, displacing the U.S. Dollar or others?

MOREHEAD: So, it's incredibly volatile. And this is really the first time in history people complained that a currency bad because it goes up too fast. We've had the Venezuelan bolivar and the Argentine Peso, and all these things go down. So, Bitcoin is not great for pricing coffee right now, like it's not, it's not good that. But it's great for moving money across borders for speculating, for all these use cases. And in 10 or 15 years, it's going to be good for buying a coffee.

PEEBLES: How liquid is it?

MOREHEAD: Oh, they trade $60 billion a day. I mean, it's hitting massive, massive market.

KISSEL: Why isn't it any better than other cryptocurrencies?

MOREHEAD: Oh, so, that is a great point. Five, six years ago when we launched our fund, Bitcoin is really the only currency out there, cryptocurrency. Now there are hundreds. And I think its sensible investors should have, you know, a basket of currencies. And Bitcoin's only about a third of the market now. Two-thirds of the market are other currencies.

BARTIROMO: We're just getting the numbers from Morgan Stanley this morning; reporting earnings for the quarter. They reported 84 cents which is better than the estimate of 77 on revenue of 9.5 billion. That also better than expected. The stock is actually trading up now on this. Do you think you're going to see more large institutions get involved in Bitcoin trading, and why Bitcoin, we know that there are a lot of cryptocurrencies?

MOREHEAD: Yes. So, it's been a long evolution. And we just had the CME launch Bitcoin Futures. So, that credentializes the Bitcoin market. Goldman is now clearing Bitcoin Futures, and I think in the next four or five months you're going to see big wall street firms starting to trade Bitcoin. And once that happens, you're going to have other firms like State Street announce they're going to custody Bitcoin. And within 18 months, I think it's going to be just the normal thing

PEEBLES: What's the top point for having cryptocurrency? What's the -- I guess the secret special sauce of having it, why have it?

MOREHEAD: Yes, I mean, you can actually just e-mail money for free. It's really powerful, right?

BARTIROMO: But why can't I just do that through my bank?

MOREHEAD: Well, they charge you 45 bucks, right?

BARTIROMO: OK.

PEEBLES: Because you don't have the volatility. But when you transfer your money to a bank, you don't have the currency volatility. You transfer a dollar or you buy, you know, pounds or whatever you're going to buy.

MOREHEAD: So, if you want to send money from here to the U.K., you have no idea what rate are they going to charge. You have no idea how many pounds are going to pop up on the other end, and it's going to take you a couple of days and cost you 45 bucks. With Bitcoin, it's instantaneous and for free.

BARTIROMO: Incredible. Dan Morehead, thank you. Thank you so much for joining us. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday.

END

urn:contentItem:5RF9-F981-JB20-G0S4-00000-00Apple to Repatriate Profits and Create Over 20,000 Jobs; Tax Reform Is Creating a Boom; Trump Not Backing Down on The Wall; YouTube Tries to Stop Kids from Eating Tide Pods; Clinton E-mail Investigation; Report Finds Pakistan I.T. Aides Made Unauthorized Access To Servers; Investing In Cryptocurrency2018-01-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:55ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTDon Peebles, Jon Hilsenrath, Lindsay Mills, Dan Morehead, Jessie Jane DuffNEWSFinancial011801cb.231Apple to Repatriate Profits and Create Over 20,000 Jobs; Tax Reform Is Creating a Boom; Trump Not Backing Down on The Wall; YouTube Tries to Stop Kids from Eating Tide Pods; Clinton E-mail Investigation; Report Finds Pakistan I.T. Aides Made Unauthorized Access To Servers; Investing In CryptocurrencyMaria Bartiromo, Lauren Simonetti, Cheryl Casone, Mary Kissel

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Apple said to contribute a massive $350 billion over the next five years the technology titan will create over 20,000 jobs. Apple says it's paying it one time $38 billion tax bill to bring the cash it has previously kept overseas.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TOM COOK, CEO, APPLE: What we've been advocating for awhile is the ability to bring that back without a huge penalty. We like the repatriation agreement on the corporate tax side and we are going to bring the vast majority of it here.

BARTIROMO: The move helped drive another record close on Wall Street yesterday. Take a look at his numbers. The Dow Jones industrial average end of the session above 26,000 for the first time ever yesterday, up 322 points. Just eight trading days since it crossed the 25,000 mark, up one and a quarter percent on the Dow, better than 1 percent on the Nasdaq, up almost 1 percent on the S&P yesterday.

Let's check futures right now. We're looking at a bit of a pullback this morning. Investors waiting for key earnings in the banking sector. Morgan Stanley set to report later this morning, as soon as those numbers come in we will bring them to you. Meanwhile Morgan Stanley shares right now down two thirds of a percent ahead of its quarterly numbers.

In Europe this morning the major indices look like this, the FT 100 down 1/2 of 1 percent, the CAC Quarante in Paris and the DAX index in Germany up fractionally.

Asia overnight stocks were mostly higher. There was strong economic news out of China overnight, the economy there 6.9 percent last year, it was a bit higher than expectations, it marks the first annual acceleration of growth for China in seven years.

Plus, it is shutdown showdown. Lawmakers battling over immigration with just hours left, Republicans pushing the short-term spending bill fixes, the latest effort comes down to the wire in our nation's capital. And YouTube looking to clean things up. Holy website plastic crackdown on the dangerous Tide pod videos taking the internet by storm. All of the stories coming up.

Joining me to talk all about it CFRA investment strategist Lindsay Mills. Peebles Corporation founder chairman and CEO Don Peebles, in the "Wall Street Journal" editorial board member, Fox News contributor, Mary Kissel. Great to see you.

MARY KISSEL, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good morning everybody. What's on the agenda?

KISSEL: The budget showdown. We cannot have government shut down. It's incredible to me to see Democrats turned down a deal that would give certainty to the military, that would fund their children's healthcare program, and gives him more non-entitlement spending. So, it is giving them more money. Republicans are willing to eat that. Why won't Democrats come to the table?

BARTIROMO: All the while they said border security is important. Funding the military is important. When push comes to shove, not there.

DON PEEBLES, FOUNDER, PEEBLES CORPORATION: Typical drama on the Potomac. It always happens and sometimes they close it down but most often they work it out. It is a negotiating ploy.

BARTIROMO: When it is shut down, funding for much of the government still goes on.

PEEBLES: Absolutely, it is relatively minor.

BARTIROMO: We're talking about the implication of that. Coming up joining the conversation, White House Deputy Press Secretary Hogan Gidley is with us this morning. Texas Congressman Roger Williams is here. Former CEO of Home Depot as well as Chrysler, Bob Nardelli joins us.

Elevation Partners cofounder managing director Roger McNamee is here. And race car driver and entrepreneur, Danica Patrick joins us as well. Big three hours stay with us you don't want to miss a moment of it.

Let's take it over right here with this, jobs in America. President Trump headed to Pittsburgh to tout the booming economy following his historic tax cuts. Markets extended the gains yesterday with the Dow closing above 26,000 mark if for the first time ever. This is the eighth 1000-point milestone for the Dow since President Trump's 2016 victory.

Let's bring your global economics editor with the "Wall Street Journal," Jon Hilsenrath. Jon, good to see you thanks so much for being here, so Apple the latest company to talk about big investments in the United States. Bringing money back. Your reaction to what's happening. We are above 130 companies at this point doing something to give back to employees or constituents as a result of the tax plan.

JON HILSENRATH, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL", GLOBAL ECONOMICS EDITOR: The estimates I'm looking at how 1.5 to 2.5 trillion dollars parked by Americans overseas, with the new one time 15% tax, they have an incentive to bring money back. The important point here with respect to Apple is that a lot of those companies that park money overseas are tech companies and pharmaceutical companies. To the extent they are bringing money back to doing what Apple is doing investing in new jobs here, those tend to be pretty good jobs, tech jobs and pharmaceutical jobs. This is a shot in the arm to the United States economy. There's no way to doubt that.

BARTIROMO: Lindsay, this is a big deal, this is 20,000 new workers contributing $350 billion to the economy, and that one-time tax of 38 billion.

LINDSAY MILLS, CFRA INVESTMENT STRATEGIST: This is fantastic news. This is exactly what we want to see out of corporate America in response to the tax reform policy. The $30 billion, think about that, that is a humongous number they will spend in capital spending over the next five years.

My only question though, the lack of clarity within this press release. What was the reason for that? You know where the money is going to go and how incremental is it to the plans they already had in place for spending over the next five years?

HILSENRATH: They did have plans in place. Companies do this all the time kind of marketing what they have already done, but it does look like a pickup from what they talked before. Reporting on this, it looks like they are going to put money in data centers, support centers. Those are jobs that might not be concentrated just in northern California.

They will also be looking to do some investment in advanced manufacturing. It makes some sense because we are increasingly talking these days about automation. Would America companies be doing right now is not necessarily looking for the cheapest labor in the world.

They are looking out for where is the most skilled labor to run these advanced machines, and is good news Apple is seeing some of the skilled labor in the United States, frankly I think the United States of America has a lot of work to do to get its workforce trained up and skilled up for this advanced manufacturing economy that we are moving into.

BARTIROMO: That's a really good point, Jon, and the president reacted to this news. He tweeted, I promise that policies that allow Apple to bring massive amounts of money back to the United States. Great to see Apple follow through. Huge win for American workers in the United States.

In an interview with ABC News last night, Tim Cook, CEO of Apple, explain why now is the right time to bring that money back.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

COOK: We like the repatriation agreement on the corporate tax side and we are going to bring the vast majority of it here. Large parts of this are results of the tax reform and there is large parts that we would have done in any situation. I haven't spent a lot of time categorizing those two because to me this is about America.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Mary Kissel, your thoughts.

KISSEL: It is just amazing to see the CEO of Apple a company way behind Barack Obama now praising the policies of a president that most of their executive team can't stand. It goes to show you all you have to do is align incentives here, reduce the burdens on business, incentivize to invest and hire people, and they'll do it. We are not going out with companies for reverse mergers. Remember those? Because they don't have to, because the companies are incentivized to bring the money back.

HILSENRATH: Maria, can I make one other point on what Apple is doing. There is a PR element to what is going on here. Apple and a lot of the other big tech companies like Google, Facebook, Amazon are getting a lot of flak right now for getting too powerful. But what Apple is trying to do is demonstrate give back to the United States of America. We are not about addicting your children to iPhones and tuning them out at the dinner table. So, there is definitely a big PR push going on here.

BARTIROMO: That's a very good point. Don Peebles, you are a businessman, tell us how you see it.

PEEBLES: What I see is amplification of the impact on the over-regulation of our economy. If you look at the run, 6 to 8000-point since he's been president. That's a result of the optimism of being able to freely do business with a reasonable level of regulations and the tax policy that will reward job generation.

We a going to see these tax policies and the deregulation propelled the economy for the next 3 to 4 years.

BARTIROMO: So, this is just beginning.

PEEBLES: Absolutely, just the beginning. You will see that across all sectors. Right now, we're looking at the tech sector, in other sectors in manufacturing who have kept their money out of the country. We have seen bonuses paid out to employees in anticipation of the tax change by auto manufacturers and others.

We are just going to see more of that. We are at a point right now of essentially full employment. Where unemployment is right now we will see some significant wage growth and that is going to be a bit of a danger on how is the Fed going to react to significant wage increase because in reality we never needed New York and other places to impose a minimum wage, the market is doing, and you can hire people for minimum wage anymore because it is so competitive.

MILLS: And corporations are not just hoarding the benefits that are getting from the taxes, and they are not just paying it out to shareholders, sure there are some companies like Bank of America that is going to increase buyback in dividends and things like that, but you see across the board, Fed Ex, united healthcare, they are raising earnings-per- share estimates, and they are investing in the companies and their employees. And by the way Apple, Bloomberg reported they are giving their employees $2500 stock grants.

BARTIROMO: You know what, Lindsay mentioned in the commercial or in the break, the Apple news doesn't include any buyback news which is really a good point. It's not like they are saying we are going to buy back stock. They are talking about investing like you said data centers four 350 billion over five years. Jon.

HILSENRATH: They are. I want to make one other point about what Don said. This is all happening in the context of very low unemployment economy, 4.1 percent unemployment. And that is a big issue for the Fed, it could lead the Fed to tighten monetary policy more aggressively than it planned. So that is a risk. On the positive side, it could lead to the wage increases that we have been waiting for years.

PEEBLES: One other things I would say also, look, I think that in reality, in the real-world interest rates are already well above the index. The index margin was far greater. Most commercial debt tied to Libor as opposed to prime.

The market is already building in wage increases because to be competitive, employers have to do that. Businesses also are doing what we always do. Invest in our companies. It's only been this environment in the last eight years under President Obama were business has been bad thing and somehow or another we are not investing in their infrastructure. We always invest in our infrastructure.

It is actually the public sector that his derelict investing in infrastructure in maintaining their facilities.

BARTIROMO: Just the rhetoric of the last eight years. You didn't build that. Pay your fair share. Sort of put companies in a frozen position in terms of let me sit on the cash because we don't know what's around the corner in terms of new big government ideas.

We've got to talk about the bad news. Congress has only until tomorrow at midnight deliver a partial government shutdown. We're expecting a vote on the Republican short-term spending bill today, Democrats say they will not vote for anything that does not include a solution for DACA. White House Chief of Staff John Kelly said last night, he is optimistic that some deal will be reached and lay out the president's demands on immigration. Here is he with Brett Baier

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN KELLY, WHITE HOUSE CHIEF OF STAFF: The president sees we should control the nuclear family. If they are married of course the wife would come in. If you have minor children than the minor children will come in. But not the parents, not extended families.

BRETT BAIER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: How much money does the need for the law?

KELLY: Roughly 700 miles of wall, additional wall, and also to include the fencing that is there, some of it's only barriers to vehicle traffic, about $20 billion. There's no doubt in my mind there is going to be a deal.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Jon, you agree with that on the implications of a government shutdown?

HILSENRATH: There will be a deal at some point. The question is whether it's after the government shut down or before. I think that my message to people on this is just get used to it because we are in an election year. There's a great deal at stake in these elections.

Democrats want to take the house and the senate, they want to go after this president, there is going to be a lot of confrontation, and I would not be at all surprised, look, the deal they are talking about is a short-term deal. Even if they do this one, they will be back at the table in a month. I wouldn't be at all surprised if at some point in the next few months, there is a government shutdown, and everyone is porting fingers at each other.

BARTIROMO: Thoughts on this?

PEEBLES: I think this is ridiculous. By the way, what do they tell you when you fly commercial airlines, if there is a catastrophic incident, put a mask over your own face first, then look out for everyone else and your babies and so forth. Going to paralyze the country over an immigration policy that's not an urgent circumstance right now. It's ludicrous. The Democrats should lead us put our government budget and control, move it forward and deal with these issue, in a more reasonable and thoughtful process

KISSEL: Republican should know that Republicans will be blamed for the shut down even if it's Democrats that don't come to the table. I don't know if the president understands that. I hope that he does. BARTIROMO: Jon Hilsenrath, thank you, sir. We will see you soon. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Snow, ice, record called in the South killing at least 10 people. Cheryl Casone with all of the details.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN HOST: That's right. Residents in the South had more than they could handle from mother nature yesterday, one of those 10 fatalities included a baby who was in a car that skidded off an overpass into a canal in New Orleans. At least four people died in the Louisiana.

Take a look at Texas. Freezing temperatures make for hazardous driving in the Houston area. Gridlock on highway 59 with icy patches on the overpasses. Many drivers had to turn around and take the nearest exit to get off of the freeway.

Live pictures we are getting operations underway to remove this plane that almost plunged into the Black Sea with 168 people on board. A live picture out of Turkey. A Boeing 737 it skidded off a runway while it was landing in northern Turkey before it hit the hill and slid down the hill. The plane finally stopped into the mud on the hill.

Everybody on board was safe and evaluated from the aircraft. A very long operation to get this plane off of the hill.

Check this out. This car isn't what you think it is. A police officer in Montreal was about to ticket this for being in a snow removal zone. When he discovered it's not a real car. Turns out an artist made the back to the future DeLorean look-alike from snow. He was just trying to mess up the police basically. He did write up a ticket for him but on the ticket he wrote you made our night. The next morning it was destroyed because they had to because it was in the snow removal zone.

BARTIROMO: That's amazing.

CASONE: Pretty good, right.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it looks like a real car. Thank you, Cheryl, we'll take a break and when we come back putting an end to an alarming and potentially deadly trend. YouTube now cracking down on the Tide pod challenge videos. Plus demanding more answers in the Hillary Clinton email probe, FBI director chief of staff takes the hot seat on capitol hill today facing questions about why the presidential candidate was not charged. We will get into that next. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: YouTube cracking down videos of the Tide pod challenge, this is a dangerous game where teens are posting videos of themselves getting the laundry detergent pods. Lauren Simonetti with all the details.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Just so you are aware, these are the detergent pods that have warnings smacked all over the packs that you buy them in. BARTIROMO: OK.

urn:contentItem:5W7G-5CN1-F0C5-X2P8-00000-00Apple to reveal glimpses of its next era of apps, devices2019-05-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:55ZLexisNexisApple to reveal glimpses of its next era of apps, devicesMark Gurman

Company expected to unveil new approach to apps, a more independent Apple Watch and more at next week's WWDC.

Apple's developer conference beginning Monday will move the company closer to a future in which the iPhone is no longer the central cog for other products and services.

Chief Executive Officer Tim Cook and other leaders will make a keynote presentation at the Worldwide Developers Conference in San Jose to unveil updates of Apple's operating systems and a new approach to apps.

The changes will showcase Apple's new generation of devices and software: Apple Watches that are more independent from iPhones, iPads with software that reduces the need for a laptop, apps that run on any Apple device, and growth areas such as augmented reality and personal health-care management, according to people familiar with the plans.

While the developer conference is software-focused, the company often sprinkles new hardware announcements in at the event. This year, Apple won't show off a new Apple Watch or iPhone hardware until the fall, but has considered previewing the new Mac Pro at the conference.

Watch Independence

When Apple launched the Watch in 2015, it was positioned as the next major product after the iPhone. But sales haven't reached iPhone levels and the Watch still relies on the handset. After adding cellular connectivity support to the device two years ago, the company will use its next software update, watchOS 6, to further break it free from the iPhone by adding an on-board App Store, new apps like a calculator and voice recorder, and new messaging features.

iPad as PC Replacement

Apple has pushed the iPad as a laptop replacement for years. But many pro users have noted that while the hardware is capable enough, the software is still behind. WWDC will reveal new efforts to bridge that gap. The company plans enhancements to the home screen and new features around using multiple apps at once to help the iPad satisfy more of your computing needs.

Unified App Strategy

Developers will get new tools to build iOS apps for Mac laptops and desktop computers, essentially unifying Apple's app ecosystem. This follows last year's rollout of iPad versions of Apple's News, Voice Memos, Home, and Stocks apps on the Mac. The expectation is that single versions of all apps will eventually be able to run on every Apple device. As part of the shift, more underlying technologies will also merge.

"The transition might not be finished for a couple of years, but this is the strongest push Apple has made toward the unification of its two platforms," said developer Steven Troughton-Smith. "Apple and developers can put more effort into one version of things instead of having to build everything twice."

New Apps

Apple is also ensuring its own core apps are up to scratch after letting some languish in favor of system-wide features. The company is readying major revamps of the Reminders and Health apps and tweaks for Maps, Messages, Apple Books, Home, and Mail. It's also planning to merge Find my iPhone and Find my Friends into a single app.

Augmented Reality

Since getting into augmented reality in 2017, Apple has added new AR features to its iPhone and iPad software annually. But until Apple launches its AR glasses, the technology, which superimposes 3-D images over views of the real world, is unlikely to take off. At first, the headset will probably need an iPhone for certain tasks. Internal versions of iOS 13 have begun to add technology that supports a future headset, according to people familiar with its development. Apple is unlikely to talk about this publicly at WWDC, but the moves indicate the company is ramping up development of the glasses, which could be showcased as early as 2020.

End of iTunes

iTunes has been the way Apple users listen to music, watch movies and TV shows, hear podcasts, and manage their devices for almost two decades. This year, Apple is finally ready to move into a new era. The company is launching a trio of new apps for the Mac Music, TV, and Podcasts to replace iTunes. That matches Apple's media app strategy on iPhones and iPads. Without iTunes, customers can manage their Apple gadgets through the Music app.

Health

Congress vows to pursue regulation of big tech with open mind

Big tech is armed and ready for the antitrust fight

Editorial: What Big Tech has to fear from federal inquiry

Tech giants under fire: Is antitrust action the answer?

Apple uses developers conference to bid adieu to iTunes, show new system updates

Health care has become a fundamental part of many Apple products. For this year, beyond the revamped Health app for iPhones, the company will push into monitoring hearing health " how loud the external environment is and how loud you're playing sound on your device or headphones. It also plans more comprehensive menstrual cycle tracking on iPhones, and a pair of health apps for the Apple Watch: menstrual cycle tracking and pill reminders. There will also be a new Sleep Mode for Apple mobile devices and better support for hearing aids.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60RX-VB11-JC8S-D16G-00000-00Apple touts H-E-B job growth as it battles App Store scrutiny2020-09-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:55ZLexisNexisAPg. A001Apple touts H-E-B job growth as it battles App Store scrutinyDwight Silverman

Apple on Wednesday highlighted Texas and the regional grocer H-E-B as success stories in an app economy that is creating thousands of jobs as the tech giant fights back against a rebellion by some of its highest-profile developers and increased scrutiny by federal and state regulators.

Apple has come under fire from app developers chafing at the rules of the company's App Store marketplace, particularly the 30 percent cut it takes from sales of apps, products and services sold through the platform. State and federal officials, meanwhile are worried that Apple's tight control of the App Store may be anti-competitive.

Apple's response has brought Texas and H-E-B into the debate over the power and reach of Big Tech and its impact on the economy. Apple cited San Antonio-based H-E-B, which launched a revamped version of its shopping app for both iOS and Android devices in December, as an example of the good the App Store does for jobs and the economy.

Apple said the number of H-E-B's active monthly iOS users increased by 1,050 percent since the launch, and the grocer added more than 150 new employees to its digital team. Texas accounted for 36,000 jobs, or more than 10 percent of nearly 300,000 new jobs across the country that Apple says apps based on its iOS operating system have created since April 2019.

Only California, with 169,000 new iOS app-related jobs, had more, the company said.

There are 2.1 million jobs in the United States related to software made for iOS apps, it said, an increase of about 10 percent nationally over the 1.9 million jobs the company touted in August 2019 . The company said that apps have provided a refuge from the COVID-19 pandemic as Americans "seek out new and safe ways to learn, work and stay engaged with friends and family during the pandemic."

Pandemic spike

Mike Georgoff, chief product officer for H-E-B Digital, said in an interview that about half of the increase in monthly users came since the pandemic began in the United States. Usage of the Android version experienced similar growth, he said.

The new version of the app turned on the ability to place delivery and curbside orders, something that previously had been possible only via H-E-B's website.

"Our consumer strategy is to focus on mobile first," Georgoff said. "These devices have taken over our lives. They are in our customers' pockets and in their hands as they shop in our stores."

He said the 150 new digital hires include employees who work on both the iOS and Android apps, as well as the website.

Apple doesn't take a cut of sales of physical goods, so the 30 percent commission doesn't apply to products sold through H-E-B's app, Georgoff said.

Sucharita Kodali, a retail analyst with Forrester Research, said more than half of e-commerce now takes place on mobile devices, and retailers are encouraging app use.

"There are certain functions you can get with an app that you can't get on a mobile website, and retailers can capture more data about customers," Kodali said.

In late July, Apple CEO Tim Cook was one of four Big Tech executives who appeared before a congressional hearing examining alleged antitrust behavior by his company, Amazon, Facebook and Google. In addition, the U.S. Justice Department and a coalition of state attorneys general - including Texas' Ken Paxton - are investigating Apple's app store rules.

Last month, Epic Games openly challenged Apple's required 30 percent commission on in-app purchases by letting users of its hit title Fortnite pay Epic directly for virtual currency. Epic did the same with Google, which also requires a 30 percent commission from sales out of its Play Store for Android devices. Both Apple and Google banned Fortnite.

But Apple went a step further, threatening to cut off all developers whose apps use the Epic's Unreal Engine, which generates the graphics and physics for a game. A federal judge ruled that Apple could ban Fortnite but not other games.

Apple has been criticized by other tech giants, including Microsoft and Facebook, for its app store rules. Microsoft wanted to introduce games that stream from servers into an iOS app, which Apple would not approve. And Apple told Facebook it couldn't tell users of a paid event service that Apple takes its 30 percent cut of what the customers would pay to Facebook.

Quelling revolt

Apple argues that its rules protect customers from malicious software and provides quality control. It says the 30 percent cut is a fair price for providing vetting and e-commerce services to developers who sell through its app store.

On Monday, Apple went live with changes to its App Store that allow developers to challenge rules and suggest changes, as well as not delaying bug-fix releases if a rule violation against that app is pending. The changes were planned before the Fortnite brouhaha and were seen as an attempt to quell a brewing developer revolt.

Forrester's Kodali said Apple's Wednesday news release was "part of the typical PR playbook of Big Tech."

"Apple is kind of getting beat up a bit; there are a lot of companies ganging up on them," she said. "They need to own the narrative and say, 'Hey, hey, we are really good for society, we do a lot of good things, our apps create jobs.'"

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W8F-V591-JCHV-V2P6-00000-00Apple Touts New Privacy Features as Potential Regulation Looms2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:55ZLexisNexisApple Touts New Privacy Features as Potential Regulation LoomsAnnie Gaus

New features in iOS include restrictions on location sharing and a 'Login with Apple' option.

Apple unleashed a at WWDC this week, many of them focused on a salient message for consumers: Apple cares about privacy.

Across its software platforms, Apple introduced new privacy-centric features aimed at helping customers guard their personal data more closely. Apple shares were up 3.6% on Tuesday after dipping on Monday on concerns of a possible antitrust investigation by the government.

Several of the new privacy features were baked into iOS13, Apple's next-generation iPhone operating system that's due out this fall. They included an option to have Apple auto-generate a random email address when you sign on to new services, and a new setting that allows you to share location data with an app only once before the permission is revoked. Apple will also bar apps from scanning your bluetooth as a loophole in finding your location, and will bar third-party advertising and analytics in children's apps.

"For the first time, you can share your location to an app just once and then require it to ask you again next time it wants it," said Apple's head of software engineering, Craig Federighi, of the location sharing feature. "If you do choose to grant an app the ability to continually monitor your location in the background, we'll give you reports so you'll know what they're up to."

Perhaps the biggest privacy surprise was a new "Login with Apple" offering, Apple's answer to similar capabilities from Facebook and Google that have been a feature of the Internet economy for years. What makes Apple's sign-in tool different is that, according to Apple, it won't track users that use the feature to create logins for third party apps and services, whereas Facebook and Google feed data gleaned from those logins for their advertising businesses.

Apple has long sought to position itself as a privacy-focused tech giant that isn't in the business of hoarding or selling user data. But Monday's privacy announcements were especially notable given reports that the U.S. Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission are into whether Amazon, Alphabet, Facebook and Apple are abusing their size to freeze out competitors.

That action is one culmination of growing criticism by regulators and lawmakers that major tech firms wield too much power over markets and consumers' lives. In recent months, prominent politicians such as presidential hopeful Sen. Elizabeth Warren have called for a breakup of Big Tech.

Any antitrust investigation of Apple will focus on whether its App Store marketplace is anti-competitive -- an issue that's also under review by the U.S. Supreme Court. But data privacy issues may well arise in regulatory probes of Facebook or Alphabet, and the issues has emerged as a winning one for both political parties as well as with consumers.

"It's a real opportunity to be a market differentiator," said Matt Dumiak, director of privacy services at CompliancePoint, of Apple's new privacy offerings.

Dumiak added that with more states passing privacy legislation, it's only a matter of time before a federal law compels Big Tech to be accountable to regulators, and not just consumers, in how they handle privacy and security.

"We may not think of it as a priority for this administration, but it very well could be," he added. "I wouldn't be surprised if within two years we see privacy legislation at the federal level."


Apple, Alphabet and Facebook areholdings in Jim Cramer's. Want to be alerted before Cramer buys or sells these stocks? .

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60G8-45X1-JCSC-J1DK-00000-00Apple tried to lure Amazon's video app by offering a lower 15% fee, email shows2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:55ZLexisNexisNEWSApple tried to lure Amazon's video app by offering a lower 15% fee, email showsKif Leswing

An email released by the House Antitrust Subcommittee on Wednesday show negotiations between Amazon and Apple over revenue sharing from the Amazon Prime Video app. Apple executive Eddy Cue emailed Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos in 2016 suggesting Apple would take a... An email released by the House Antitrust Subcommittee on Wednesday show negotiations between Amazon and Apple...

An email released by the House Antitrust Subcommittee on Wednesday show negotiations between Amazon and Apple over revenue sharing from the Amazon Prime Video app. Apple executive Eddy Cue emailed Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos in 2016 suggesting Apple would take a...

An email released by the House Antitrust Subcommittee on Wednesday show negotiations between Amazon and Apple over revenue sharing from the Amazon Prime Video app. Apple executive Eddy Cue emailed Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos in 2016 suggesting Apple would take a 15% fee on subscriptions that signed up through the app, which is lower than Apple's customary 30% fee for most in-app purchases. Apple says that it treats all apps the same. "We apply the rules to all developers evenly," Cook testified on during Wednesday's Big Tech hearing before the House Antitrust Subcommittee. In the summer of 2017, Apple CEO Tim Cook announced that Amazon's Prime Video service would be launching on the Apple TV set-top box, after a long and noticeable absence. An email released by the House Antitrust Subcommittee on Wednesday shed new light into the negotiations that led to that announcement. It shows an Apple exec offered Amazon a 15% fee on subscriptions that signed up through the app, which is lower than Apple's customary 30% fee for most in-app purchases. The email suggests that big players can negotiate for better business terms on Apple's App Store, contradicting Apple's public stance that all apps are treated the same on its platform. "We apply the rules to all developers evenly," Cook testified on Wednesday. Software makers are required to use Apple's payment mechanism for any digital purchases inside an iPhone app. Apple typically takes 30% of the initial purchase price, including 30% from the first year of subscription services that customers buy through the app, then drops the fee to 15% in the second year of a subscription. The 30% fee is a core part of Spotify's antitrust complaint with EU regulators . In May 2016, Bezos told an interviewer that Amazon refused to sell devices like Apple TV or Google 's Chromecast on Amazon.com because it was unable to agree on terms for placing Amazon Prime Video on those devices. "When we sell those devices, we want our player — our Prime Video player — to be on the device, and we want it to be on the device with acceptable business terms," he said. "You can always get the player on the device. The question is, can you get it on there with acceptable business terms?" At some point later in the year, Bezos met with Apple senior vice president Eddy Cue and discussed business terms for this and other matters, according to the document released Wednesday. "Jeff, I really enjoyed our time together," emailed Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos in November 2016. "Here are the details of what we discussed on Prime Video — Amazon Prime Video app in iOS and Apple TV — 15% rev share for customers that signup using the app (uses our payment); no rev share for customers that already subscribe." In addition, Cue said that if Amazon was able to sell services like Showtime in its app, that Apple would only take 15% if the customer originally signed up through Apple. It's not clear if the companies ended up agreeing to the terms in the email. Although the Amazon Prime Video app appeared on Apple TV only in 2017, a version of Amazon's video app been available on iOS since 2012, and it's not known what the terms were before or after Cue's email to Bezos. Representatives for Apple and Amazon didn't respond to a request for comment. Apple's arrangement with Amazon was made public earlier this year when users discovered that the Amazon Prime Video iPhone app started to allow users to purchase digital content — movies and TV shows — inside the app using a credit card on file with Amazon. Apple said at the time that it was part of an "established program" for "premium subscription video entertainment providers." WATCH: Congress presses Apple CEO Tim Cook on whether App Store treats all developers equally

urn:contentItem:5WGY-KFH1-JCMN-Y0P0-00000-00Apple trolled Google again by erecting a giant billboard next to its controversial data-hungry smart neighborhood2019-07-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:55ZLexisNexisApple trolled Google again by erecting a giant billboard next to its controversial data-hungry smart neighborhoodIsobel Asher Hamilton

Jul 05, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Getty Apple erected a billboard boasting about its privacy record across the street from Google's sister company Sidewalk Labs in Toronto, Canada. Sidewalk Labs has received pushback over the smart neighborhood it plans to build along Toronto's eastern waterfront, which will be loaded with sensors collecting data about people. Apple similarly mocked Google with a billboard in January at CES.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.[1] Apple has trolled Google with an artfully placed billboard for the second time in seven months. CTV News Toronto reported that Apple erected a billboard across the road from Sidewalk Labs, the smart city sister company to Google whose planned smart neighbourhood in Toronto has prompted major privacy concerns. "We're in the business of staying out of yours," the billboard reads. Here is an image of it next to Sidewalk Labs:Instagram Embed: //instagram.com/p/Bzgjx0WBOE3/embed Width: 540pxAnd from another angle:Tweet Embed: //twitter.com/mims/statuses/1146527078839443456?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw New Apple billboard outside Sidewalk Toronto HQ: "We're in the business of staying out of yours." pic.twitter.com/I24iAxkXzZ[2]Alphabet-owned Sidewalk Labs plans to install sensors in the 12-acre waterfront neighborhood, which it's calling Quayside. The sensors will monitor the movements and behaviors of people walking through the area. Sidewalk has called for the creation of an independent trust to stop companies — including itself — from selling that data on to third parties without consent. Read more: Sidewalk Labs shared its $900 million plan to remake Toronto's waterfront. Local activists said it deepened their concerns.[3] Some Toronto residents remain unconvinced, however. "Sidewalk Labs proposing the laws that will regulate their behavior is like the fox proposing the design of the hen house," Toronto resident Melissa Goldstein told Business Insider[4]. Earlier this year at tech conference CES, Apple pulled a similar stunt[5], putting up a billboard next to Las Vegas' monorail system — which was emblazoned with "Hey Google" slogans. "What happens on your iPhone, stays on your iPhone," the ad read. Apple has long touted its approach to privacy over other tech companies like Google because its business model doesn't rely on amassing user data. However, this doesn't mean iPhones are impenetrable — especially since most iPhone owners use Google apps.NOW WATCH: 23 useful iPhone tricks and hidden features to make your life easier[6]See Also: urn:contentItem:5WGX-8F61-DXY7-W2VS-00000-00Apple trolled Google again by erecting a giant billboard next to its controversial data-hungry smart neighborhood2019-07-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:55ZLexisNexisApple trolled Google again by erecting a giant billboard next to its controversial data-hungry smart neighborhoodfeedback@businessinsider.com (Isobel Asher Hamilton)

Apple erected a billboard boasting about its privacy policy across the street from Google's sister company, Sidewalk Labs, in Toronto.

Getty

Apple erected a billboard boasting about its privacy record across the street from Google's sister company Sidewalk Labs in Toronto, Canada.

Sidewalk Labs has received pushback over the smart neighborhood it plans to build along Toronto's eastern waterfront, which will be loaded with sensors collecting data about people.

Apple similarly mocked Google with a billboard in January at CES.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.

Apple has trolled Google with an artfully placed billboard for the second time in seven months.

CTV News Toronto reported that Apple erected a billboard across the road from Sidewalk Labs, the smart city sister company to Google whose planned smart neighbourhood in Toronto has prompted major privacy concerns.

"We're in the business of staying out of yours," the billboard reads. Here is an image of it next to Sidewalk Labs:

Instagram Embed: //instagram.com/p/Bzgjx0WBOE3/embed Width: 540px

And from another angle:

Tweet Embed: //twitter.com/mims/statuses/1146527078839443456?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw New Apple billboard outside Sidewalk Toronto HQ: "We're in the business of staying out of yours." pic.twitter.com/I24iAxkXzZ

Alphabet-owned Sidewalk Labs plans to install sensors in the 12-acre waterfront neighborhood, which it's calling Quayside. The sensors will monitor the movements and behaviors of people walking through the area.

Sidewalk has called for the creation of an independent trust to stop companies - including itself - from selling that data on to third parties without consent.

Read more: Sidewalk Labs shared its $900 million plan to remake Toronto's waterfront. Local activists said it deepened their concerns.

Some Toronto residents remain unconvinced, however. "Sidewalk Labs proposing the laws that will regulate their behavior is like the fox proposing the design of the hen house," Toronto resident Melissa Goldstein told Business Insider.

Earlier this year at tech conference CES, Applepulled a similar stunt, putting up a billboard next to Las Vegas' monorail system - which was emblazoned with "Hey Google" slogans. "What happens on your iPhone, stays on your iPhone," the ad read.

Apple has long touted its approach to privacy over other tech companies like Google because its business model doesn't rely on amassing user data. However, this doesn't mean iPhones are impenetrable - especially since most iPhone owners use Google apps.

NOW WATCH: I switched from the $1,099 iPhone XS Max to the $479 Pixel 3a XL - and I didn't miss much

See Also:

Apple is now facing 3 privacy probes in Ireland

Apple's design team is working on projects that 'will blow you away,' Tim Cook says

Facebook, Google, and Apple are going on the defense as the battle cry to break up 'big tech' gets louder than ever

SEE ALSO: Google could be bankrupting Apple's privacy promises by handing over iPhone data to the police
